title: Benford‚Äôs Law Anomaly Detector
text:
Benford‚Äôs Law is often seen as the go-to forensic accounting tool in fraud detection.
üìà I built this interactive Shiny app to let users:

Upload their own .csv files (max. 500MB) [note: please be patient, upload time is slow‚Ä¶]
Select a numeric column to analyse
Automatically extract the first digits
Compare the digit distribution to Benford‚Äôs expected probabilities
Flag anomalies using a \(\chi^2\) (Chi-squared) test (checks whether the difference between predicted results and actual values is statistically significant)

Here is the Benford‚Äôs Law Anomaly Detector I made.
Click the link above to launch the live app hosted on shinyapps.io.


üîçWhat is Benford‚Äôs Law?
Although Simon Newcomb first noted the mathematical property, today‚Äôs widely known Benford‚Äôs Law is a curious statistical principle used in anomaly detection. It reveals that in many real-world datasets, small leading digits (i.e.¬†1) are counter-intuitively more likely to occur than large digits. This pattern seems to be present in a wide range of cases, ranging from:

üó≥ election results;
üè° street addresses;
üìä financial data;
‚ö∞Ô∏è mortality statistics;
üß™ to molecular weights.







üìê Generalised Benford‚Äôs Law: The Formula Behind the Pattern


The probability that a number begins with digit d (from 1 through 9) is:


\[
P(d) = \log_{10} \left(1 + \frac{1}{d} \right)
\]


Where:



\(P(d)\) is the probability that the first digit is \(d\)
The logarithm is base-10
This formula shows why 1 appears about 30.1% of the time, while 9 only shows up around 4.6%






üìä Benford‚Äôs Law Expected Distribution
The plot below shows the probability distribution predicted by Benford‚Äôs Law for the first digit (1‚Äì9). As you can see, the digit 1 appears ~30% of the time, while 9 appears less than 5%.

title: CGT Calculator
text:
What is Capital Gains Tax (CGT)?
CGT is levied on profit derived from the disposal of a CGT asset acquired on or after 20 September 1985, where the realisation is not undertaken in the ordinary course of carrying on a business; otherwise, the gain will be assessable under s6-5.
According to s108-5(2), CGT assets encompass: land and buildings (including rental properties), shares in a company, units in a unit trust, rights and options, leases, goodwill, debts owed to a taxpayer, foreign currency, and cryptocurrencies (such as Bitcoin).
The net capital gain derived from the disposal of a CGT asset is considered as statutory income and is included in the taxpayer‚Äôs income tax return under Item 18 (s105-5).
However, if an overall net capital loss arises, the amount is not deductible in the income year it occurred. Instead, it is carried forward indefinitely (quarantined) and applied to future capital gains.
A disposal (sale) of an asset that triggers CGT is called a CGT event. Division 104-5 identifies 56 CGT events or ways to dispose of such assets. However, two events occur in 95% of cases:

A1: Disposal of a CGT Asset
These include the change of legal ownership (sale, transfer, exchange, gift) or destruction of such assets, where timing is usually determined by the date when the contract is signed or the date of settlement in the absence of a contract.
C1: Loss or Destruction of a CGT Asset
Here, the timing will depend on whether the taxpayer receives compensation in respect to this event.

If the CGT asset is insured, a CGT event occurs when the taxpayer first receives compensation/insurance payment.
If the CGT asset is not insured, C1 occurs when the destruction or loss happens or is first discovered. Note: capital losses are calculated as cost base minus capital proceeds, where cost base is at historical cost (not the market value at the time of destruction).

title: fbt
text:
What is Fringe Benefit Tax (FBT)?

Fringe Benefit Tax (FBT) is levied on any non-cash benefit that employers (or employers‚Äô associates/subsidiaries) provide to employees (or employees‚Äô associates) used for private purposes.

Employees for FBT purposes include: company directors, officeholders, employees, and recipients of compensation payments
Associates of employees are: their relatives (S318 ITAA36) + any other person (friend, flatmate‚Ä¶).

FBT exclusions

Payments of: salary/wages, cash allowances (except a living-away-from-home allowance), superannuation, benefits under Div83A scheme, ETP and specific exemptions under FBTAA (1986)
Payments to non-employees: genuine contractors, clients, shareholders and suppliers

Common fringe benefits include: company car, home electricity/home telephone bills, private health insurance, children‚Äôs school fees, private holiday, low or interest-free loans, entertainment (meals, free concert ticket‚Ä¶)
Benefits are grouped into the 12 categories

Car fringe *
Debt waiver fringe
Loan fringe *
Expense payment fringe *
Housing fringe
Living-away-from-home allowance fringe
Board fringe
Meal entertainment fringe
Tax-exempt body entertainment fringe
Property fringe *
Car parking fringe
Residual fringe (i.e.¬†benefits that do not fall under any of the other eleven categories)

title: fbt
text:
FBT Administration

The FBT regime runs from 1 April to 31 March
FBT is a self-assessed return prepared by the employer, and is a separate form from BAS and IAS
If self-prepared, FBT must be lodged and paid by 21 May, or 25 June if lodged by a tax agent
If the taxpayer‚Äôs FBT is less than $3,000, the liability is settled in one annual payment by one of the above due dates.
If more than the threshold, the ATO requires FBT to be paid in quarterly instalments plus an annual payment of any outstanding amount, in which case Label F1 of the taxpayer‚Äôs BAS will be shown.
F1 is the annual FBT estimate provided by the ATO based on the taxpayer‚Äôs prior FBT assessment, and it is pre-printed on the Activity Statement. Taxpayers can vary (adjust) their quarterly instalments based on their updated estimate for the FBT year ending 31 March. The ATO provides several reasons for making these variations.
FBT rate typically corresponds to the highest marginal tax rate plus Medicare levy. A 47% rate currently applies across the 31 March 2022 to 31 March 2026 FBT years.
Section 136(1) of the Act broadly defines a benefit to include ‚Äúany right, privilege, service or facility‚Äù, which encompasses anything of value provided as part of or in lieu of a salary package (except for salary and wages), which is designed to reduce the income tax liability of the employee.
The taxable value of a fringe benefit must be grossed up before calculating the fringe benefit tax. Grossing up helps to equate non-cash benefits with salary levels, enabling the ATO to tax these benefits as if they were income. This process allows for a fair comparison between different types of compensation.
The gross-up factor depends on whether the employer can claim GST credit related to the cost of providing the benefit. Type 1 fringes are GST credit claimable, whereas Type 2 fringes are those that are not Type 1 benefits (i.e., either the benefit is GST-free or the employer is not eligible to claim an input tax).


Further details and official requirements are published on the ATO‚Äôs website.
